The busperson was a great guy, so I tipped him instead. Too bad he has to work with such a clueless waiter. Last meal at Pellegrini's, that's for sure.
author: Denny S.

description: We were walking by North Beach and saw that place thinking that because it smelled good, it'll taste good. I ordered the chicken Parmesan, my wife got the salmon & eggplan and a friend some dessert. NONE of the dishes we got was close to good taste. The chicken was over fried, the pasta was cold, the salmon was over cooked and bad fishy taste, and the dessert had no taste at all. I dont think that this place should exist in North Beach in the middle of the fine italian dinning district
author: Motaz H.

description:
Do you trust Italians after watching the Soprano's and God Father so many times.
Yes, I do.
I do trust Italian because they are so stubborn about everything.
Specially for Pasta.
Italians don't give shit.
They do know exact what is right.
So,
You'll be in the deep truble if you over cooked pasta, period.
You are going down with over cooked pasta forever.
That's how serious they are about cooking.
There is no mediocre Italians.
They are all hard-core in some degree..
Yes, I do trust them.
well,
about this place, I think 100% Italian.

I went there on a Saturday night about 7:30 with my GF, my yonger son and his female friend but with No Reservation.
But,
Thank God,
We were so lucky that they made a table just for us even they were busy.
I had a grilled salmon, a nice fat slice with great tomato and black olive souce on it.
It was something.
Something really good.
Whenever I am having great dish, I can't hear, talk and share.

Another reason why I like this place because you can see what's going on in the kitchen.
And,
People in here, they were great. 
Hard working Profesionals.
But why 4 stars?
I didn't see any waitresses.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I had high hopes for this restaurant given all the positive reviews, and while the food was adequate, it wasn't quite special enough for me to give it even three stars.  

The greens in our mista salad were clearly not fresh -- they weren't spoiled or anything, just wilty and not as fresh as what they should be.  The gorgonzola was very smooth and light, however, and that's a plus.  I liked the cheese even though I'm not a cheese fan generally.

We then had the sausage and mushroom pizza.  The sausage was spicy and added a lot of kick to the pizza's flavor.  The crust was thin, which we liked also.  While not spectacularly tasty, it was a decent job I thought.

We also split the ravioli with meat sauce.  We read somewhere that Piazza Pellegrini is famous for its home-made ravioli and lasagna.  The ravioli itself was very smooth, soft, and palatable, but the meat sauce was very plain -- too plain in fact.  

If I have to think of one word to describe their food, it would be "ordinary."  Not terrible in any way, just not special.  Given the so-so quality of the food, we skipped dessert and went elsewhere for ice-cream instead.

The other thing that kinda bugged me about the place was that it's too small.  They had many tables outside on the sidewalk, but there was a LOT of pedestrian traffic and also many people who were waiting to get in, so it just looked very uncomfortable to be eating outside.  The restaurant inside was also very small -- they had an open kitchen, but the ventilation wasn't great.  At one point they made something smokey, and I just wanted to finish the meal and get out.  Didn't make for very comfortable dining.

So overall I'd give this place a B - not bad, adequate, but nothing spectacular or memorable, and certainly not a place I'd be thinking about again.
author: Felix Y.

description:
A solid dinner in a lively atmosphere. The bruschetta was really good, although I was disappointed the cheese on the mushroom pieces wasn't melted. 

The pasta pomodoro was very very good. Everyone else at the table seemed to be very happy with their meals as well.

The wine suggested by the server was OK. I wasn't thrilled with the wine selection, although I can't really say why. However, I feel the server listened to what we liked and made a good recommendation based on that.

Unfortunately we were running late so didn't get to sample dessert.

All in all, I would say 3.5. They didn't really do anything wrong, so rounding up to 4.
author: Lise L.

description:
Piazza Pellegrini is a terrific Restaurant in North Beach; right across from Washington Square. This was our second visit. We had an excellent Caesar salad and a charming waiter (Rosario) from Italy, recommended their "Cioppino" (we both ordered the same dish). This was the best "Cioppino" ever, exceptionally fresh, prepared authentically with high-quality ingredients and tons of crab, muscles, clams and fish served in a huge bowl. 

He also recommended the best "red" wine from Southern Italy, forgot the name (sorry), which blended extremely well with the "Cioppino". Excellent service, our waiter and waitress made sure we didn't lack anything e.g. bread, olive oil, water, and they replaced five times the big plate to discard the shells from the "Cioppino". Their bread and desserts were delicious. This restaurant has a nice ambiance and we had a wonderful evening.
author: Gigi W.

description: The food was good.  Maybe skip the shrimp appetizer. 12.95 was a little much for the 4 small prawns. We would defiantly go back for their pasta. YUM!
author: Slone F.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner recently. 

Positive: one of the few North Beach restaurants where you can get a group of 20 in the door.  Most other restaurants would most likely just turn you away in North Beach. 

Negative: The pasta with short rib Ragu came recommended. While the ribbon pasta and short rib were indeed tasty, there was definitely something wrong with the carrots that they added. I love carrots but these carrots must have been soaked in vinegar or something because it immediately gave me that weird tang in my mouth which told my brain that something wrong.  Unfortunately, my belly screamed hunger and so I continued eating a couple more until . . . I realized that there was definitely something wrong with the way the carrots were cooked.  Needless to say, I won't be coming back for the pasta with short rib ragu.  I will stick to the pizza next time.
author: Jason M.

description:
Finely prepared traditional Italian fare.  Delicious from beginning to end.  I particularly enjoyed the ravioli in pesto-cream sauce - mouth watering and the lamb chop in an herbed butter with fresh basil.  Very north, and very good.

Five dined with appetizers, full dinner, drinks, dessert and cappuccino for $155 before tip.  That's a real treat!

The atmosphere is authentic Italiano, barring the one American side-waiter, anxious to share his "dutch date" idealism ... Ick -  I thought the days of appreciation for the burning bra were long over.  However, our lead waiter was not only an Italian gentleman but sincerely gentlemanly, too.

The interior is something out of the GodFather -- I was waiting for someone with a huge chest and long coat to glide through the door.

An enjoyable venue and quite respectable cuisine.

We'll be back... Thanks, Preet, for the intro!
author: Michael O.

description:
This is not a large restaurant, but it does quite a business. My wife and I took a guest here for lunch (it was our first time) and were impressed with the service, attentiveness of the staff and especially the food. I would recommend this spot with out hesitation, and know that we will be back.

I had the Penne all a Puttanesca (Capers, black olives, anchovies, tomato sauce) which was amazing - I almost ordered a second plate! My wife had theSquash Ravioli (Butter & Sage) and found her dish to a delicious as mine. All in all a great experience!
author: Daniel H.

description: Disappointing!  The two stars are given for the cute look of the place, huge menu, and nice waiter who served us.  But our meals sorely missed the mark, especially since my general experience in North Beach is that most Italian restaurants there are usually pretty decent.  I had the arugula salad with beets.  Some of the leaves were wilted and slimy, not okay, and the beets were floppy instead of firm.  For the main course I had the veal osso buco with side of risotto.  The veal was okay, not great, and the rice was just odd -- very strong saffron flavor that did not match the savory of the veal onion/carrot sauce.  Strange combination.  My husband had the veal parmigiana, which was ordinary at best.  While the waiter was kind, the server who took our drink order got it wrong and then insisted it was right.  The menu is also overpriced.  I won't eat here again.
author: Molly R.

description:
The waiters and waitresses are very nice and serious about their work. Being Italian, they're a rather jovial bunch as well. I highly recommend trying the minestrone (they split an order for us three ways without charging extra) soup, and the homemade ravioli with squash stuffing. The sweetness of the squash offsets the olive oil. 

The restaurant has a nice, cheerful ambiance.
author: Nicole Y.

description:
I decided to take my gf here for dinner on Valentine's Day. 

Service: waiter was very friendly and recommended a great half-bottle of chianti to go with our meal. On the other hand, it took well over 15 minutes to get our check. In his defense, we were finishing dinner around 930, and couples were coming in to eat as well.

Reservations: do make them. Yes, you can try to put your name down when you enter, but the place is small and you may not get your pick of seats. I made reservations a few days prior and we got seated by the window, very romantic. They also have seats outside, but I didn't see any heat lamps, so if beware if you wanna brave it outside.

Menu: good choices. Major kudos for not sticking patrons with the Valentine's Day prix fixe menu. I know some of you like it, but sometimes it's nice to have a dinner with choices and not 4-6 courses. Good vegetarian options, as my gf ordered the eggplant parmagiana, which she loved. I ordered the linguine with chicken over pesto. I rarely eat pesto but I think this might have gotten me hooked.  Went well with the spinach salad and paired well with the chianti.

We shared the ice cream with espresso. Tasty, but after a few minutes, it pretty much turned into an iced coffee. Next time, with a bigger appetite we're having the tiramisu.

Overall, I had a great time. You always gotta deal with parking in North Beach, so be prepared. Get there early, take a cab if you take the BART, or cough up $20 at the lot next door.  Very romantic North Beach spot, for all the guys looking for places to take your lady in North Beach, I'd recommend here, Panta Rei, or Steps of Rome. Food is on par with North Beach, but ambiance and the fact that it's a quiet place to take your date or significant other separates it from the rest of the NB eateries.
author: Neil N.

description:
Staff that speaks Italian.... so ya know the food is great!!!

Gnocchi is the shit!!!  Fantastic gnocchi.  The food is good Italian food, but the piece de la resistance is the gnocchi.
author: Matthew F.

description: First impression... Nice little cozzy spot. We sat outside, but there wasn't that great of a view as I had read from other yelp reviews. It all depends if there are cars parked infront, which there usually are. The food was average, wouldn't rave about it. If you are going to check it out, the lasagna was the one of the better things on the menu. Overall, I wasn't impressed.
author: Ivannia D.

description: Great people watching from this vantage point.  Sat on the patio and enjoyed a delicious sausage panino--sweet, spicy, perfect.  They were unfortunately out of the pork panino we originally wanted.  The house cabernet was also quite good.  Server was friendly, people watching was prime.  All in all, a great experience and we will be back!
author: Bailey H.

description:
Just moved in close by here and wandered in last night having read no yelp reviews...  As you can imagine, i was terrified.

Very solid place for the money.  I had the Gambini appetizer, arugola salad, pasta with short rib ragu and a prosciutto pizza.  All were good, although none exceptional.  

For $30 the Pellegrini Carignon was perfect.  

The homemade limoncello on the house at the end sealed the 4th star.  

AND -- as a special treat for all you curious cats out there -- I learned that "Pellegrini" means "Pilgrims".  If you dont know, now you know.
author: Brad C.

description:
The wonders and pitfalls of this place are fairly simple - 
Great wine list countered by higher-per-bottle price than I like to pay
Charming, cute Italian servers countered by long waits for anything but a table to sit at
Fantastic osso-bucco and espresso, but meh on the bread/oil combo
Great location for outside dining countered by tourists staring at your food as they walk past.

Overall, I'd go there again, but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Starlight M.

description:
Okay, I don't know how many times I've reiterated this.  I don't cook, if I can avoid it.  I just don't like all the work associated with cooking.  ESPECIALLY DURING THE HOLIDAY SEASON!!!!  If I had a dishwasher and a nice stove...well...it might be another story.  Yet, if all restaurants were like Piazza Pelligrini, I might not cook even if I had a dishwasher and top of the line stove.   

BOTTOM LINE: 

-This restaurant was open for Christmas 
-The Buon Natale specials were fantastic. The portion sizes were adequate and  I ordered the Wild Mushroom Risotto, which was savory and cheesy, while the boyfriend ordered the Australian Rack of Lamb, which was delcious, albeit slightly overcooked.
-2 salads, 2 entrees, 1 glass of wine, 1 glass of champagne = approx $80

This is a place to try if you are in North Beach.  There is outdoor seating with heat lamps and makes for a good romantic spot to enjoy the day or a great meetup place for friends.

Street parking only, which can be limited, as North Beach is the hopping spot during the weekend and evenings.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
We have been going here for sometime now and tonight was just awful.  Waited 40 minutes for appetizers and another 20 for our main course.  They kept telling us, another two minutes, another two minutes.  Supposedly there was new head chef in the kitchen.   The least they could do was comp us a drink or something.  Dinner was ok, it wasn't like the way it was before.

Yeah, I won't be going back there again or recommending it to friends.
author: Buddy R.

description: Excellent spot. The food was great, the service was terrific. They were able to whip up a special pasta app I felt like. Kids loved the pizza and the roasted chicken was great too. Excellent place for a good, casual, relaxed meal.
author: William C.

description: Thought o really liked their bruschetta here... Remembered them being oh so good with crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside bread with a super large portion of tomatoes doused in olive oil... But we came back to burnt bread and not as many tomatoes. Sadness! The food overall was only okay that night.
author: Mas M.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped by Piazza Pellegrini last night for dinner...overall, it was a great experience. The staff was friendly and warm, and extremely prompt in their service. We started with the portobello mushroom appetizer, which had a red wine reduction sauce and creamy polenta. Soooo delicious! The polenta totally rocked my world. For entrees, I had the crab ravioli, and my boyfriend had the gnocchi. His was much better than mine...the crab was overcooked, and a little bit fishy. Overall, it was a good experience though. It's right in the neighborhood, so I'm sure we'll be back! 
*3 1/2 Stars*
author: Brianne K.

description: The ambiance is pretty nice and right across from Washington square Park.  I had the Chicken Parmigiana and my wife had a pasta dish that she really liked.  I have to say my dish tasted like they may have run up the street to Pasta Pomodoro and slipped in the back door and threw it on one of their plates.  It wasn't nothing to write home about.
author: James H.

description: Overpriced! A plate of spinach ravioli was 18 dollars and didn't taste all that great. It was a small Serving as well. This place is way overpriced
author: vik c.

description:
I love this place - I have a hard time not suggesting it to people when I am in North Beach. 

The first time I went there was on a 'Food Crawl' with FIERI (young Italian group) -- think of a food crawl as a bar crawl but you remember the last stop!

This was our first stop (aka appetizers) and hands-down the best.  There was pizzas, pastas, bruschetta, grilled veggies and the list goes on... It was so tough, the food was sooo good... but it was our first stop... and in the end I think I would have been happy to just stay there!

Since, I have been back and will keep going back! The pizzas are wonderful but my favorite is the Pappardelle Pellegrini ($13.95) which is a Ribbon pasta with a short rib ragu -- YUMMY!

The service has ranged from ok to great.  I think sometime, you need to tell waiters if you are in a hurry...  North Beach tends to be a place you go and enjoy long meals... so don't expect them to be in your face and throwing the bill to you... it would ruin the atmosphere :)
author: julia d.

description: The fried calamari/shrimp was very good. If you like a little spice, try the spicy olive oil for some kick. The gnocchi was bland though and the chicken parmigiana was good but nothing to write home about. The chicken with prosciutto was the best plate and would recommend it.
author: David R.

description:
Crab Ravioli. Let's just leave it at that. Spinach pasta with fresh shredded crab meat stuffed to the brim, perfectly al dente so it gave you a fight when you wanted to devour it. 

Waiters are very friendly and attentive. I would give this place a shot. Great locale as being sort of on the edge of NB and away from the really annoying tourists, kitty from the park so you can go lay on the grass when you are too stuffed to walk any further. 

Authentic... check it out.
author: Annie T.

description:
Nice, fun, decent (but SALTY) food... a bit pricey but not bad... overall, nothing stellar but certainly not bad. 

That pretty much sums it up.  I had the penne arriabiata; it was good but overly salty. My friend had the linguini with pesto; it was decent (but as another reviewer pointed out, I could make better pesto at home.) And the pesto was overly salty.  KEYWORD:  SALTY. "NaCl" for you chemists.

Dear Piazza Pellegrini:  PLEASE hold back on the salt... you could use 40% less salt on EVERYTHING, and it would still be JUST AS GOOD.  It wasn't just salty as in "a little heavy on the salt", it was salty as in "makes your mouth curdle" in the way that it would if you took a beer bong and dumped in two cans of Morton salt.  KEYWORD: SODIUM

Did I mention it was SALTY?  The service was stellar... extra employees to spare, and they were all very helpful and attentive.  They should have kept one of the guys behind and had him do full-time salt monitoring of the chefs. The cute blonde girl outside was nice, but pretty useless except for getting male tourists to come in.

Would I go back?  Yes, if it was the only Italian place in North Beach. Nope, I'd rather try somewhere new. Or walk one more block to hit Pasta Pomodoro, which is always reliable (if not exciting) and is $3 to $5 cheaper per dish. And less salty. Actually, I would indeed go back IF I were to come back and find reviewers saying they've lightened up on the salt.

Sorry, Piazza Pellegrini, you tried hard but you left a taste in my mouth. It wasn't a BAD taste at all... but it sure was SALTY.
author: Em-eye-gee P.

description:
Easily the best Italian food I've had in the city thusfar.

Generally speaking, North Beach is spotty for good Italian food. In theory, the entire 'hood should be packed to the gills with genuine authentic restaurants, but there are way too many pretenders masquerading as The Real Deal out there. 

Piazza Pellegrini may very well be The Real Deal. 

They make you feel at home. One of the other patrons sitting at the bar bought a round for our entire table. The server was amazing, the owner was friendly & hands-on, & the menu was killer (all six of us were very happy with our meal).

I'll definitely be back.
author: Pete J.

description:
So its Saturday night 7:30, every place else is like 45 minute wait for a party of 8, here we walk right up and they seat us immediately.

The chef sends out an antipasti plate on the house.  Everyone's food was terrific.  They even had a great mixed vegi platter for my vegetarian girlfriend. Excellent service.  And it was like $22 each.

Gotta be the best bargain of the 8 million italian joints in the area.
author: Codester H.

description: We were walking back to our car after going to Beach Blanket Babylon and looking at the different menus as we were going down Columbus.  This place appealed to us so we went in.  Excellent pasta- a very nice fettucini alfredo with chicken and another pasta with a short rib ragu. We cleaned our plates.  Definitely will go back next time we are in the neighborhood.
author: Rhonda B.

description:
Ok. Yes, the decor is pretty cute. And yes, each of the items we ordered at dinner were tasty enough (though nothing memorable). But, I will NOT be back. Why? ... the blatant and really irritating upselling that we were subjected to.

Most of the group ordered one entree and I only ordered a simple salad (wasn't hungry)... and apparently that wasn't enough revenue. How did I know? Because on my only ordering a salad, he subjected me to several rounds of questions as to whether the salad would be enough to the point I got embarassed. Then, after the group finished placing our order, the waiter asks, "And would you like some appetizers to start with?" We didn't have interest. Then "Oh ok... well, it may be a long wait until the entrees come out..." Hmmm, no thanks. Then "Well, just want to make sure because one of the entrees takes a much longer time and I wouldn't want you ladies to get hungry in the mean time..."...and so on. Like, seriously?!

I know the dining industry is suffering, but really, this is just too much and very unpleasant.
author: Alice C.

description: Well, it's a north beach restaurant listed on OpenTable. A plus if need something at the last minute. But the experience overall is mediocre. Service is sloooow.  Pasta with ragu good, the fettucine with shrimp in cream sauce ok (my friend thought it was too bland).  Honey crostata with vanilla gelato was good.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
FANTASTIC!!!!

I am at Piazza Pellegrini about 3-4 times a month. Definitely one of my favorite Italian restaurants. I even had my birthday dinner there in April. 

The service is great; everyone is friendly. When I'm in there eating at the bar, they even help me practice my tiny bit of Italian I'm studying!

The food is delicious - I love the meat lasagna (although the lobster one looks great, but I can't do that much dairy); and the Bolognese is outstanding. The short rib ragu delish. Everything is yummy!!! For dessert, go for the Profiteroles - they use hazelnut gelato inside!

The wine list offers good prices for good wines - and a varied mix of Italian and Californian. They always offer a specials list, which is ever changing. Great half bottles available for two people, or in my case, for one!

The outdoor patio is a delight - heat lamps, people watching, can't get any better. 

Prices are very fair for the quality and quantity of food. Parking is usually never an issue for me.
author: Lindsey C.

description: I have had some very good homemade Italian meals in my life. This place tops most of them. You have to ask for the spicy EVOO. Put it on a old rubber tire and it would taste good.
author: David C.

description: My favorite restaurant in North Beach both for food and to people watch.  The owner is very accommodating and the service is terrific!  I especially enjoy the squash ravioli (seasonal of course), and the Mista salad is amazing - the best gorgonzola ever!!!!  If your in a hurry, you might want to go somewhere else.  Good, fresh food takes time - have a glass of wine and enjoy!!!
author: Kathy K.

description:
My former roommate and I ate our way through North Beach on a "walk" that turned out to be more of an eating tour. After coffee and a complimentary chocolate truffle at XOX, we went on for fresh biscotti at the Italian bakery on Green, then stopped here after being lured in by a plate of pesto pasta on a diner's table. 

We ended up being completely pleasantly surprised. Exceptionally fresh, high-quality ingredients prepared authentically and served to us by a charming waiter who was from Italy and spoke to my friend (who studied in Florence) in Italian. This is no tourist trap, cheesy atmosphere, jacked-up-prices Italian joint. It's the real thing and it's delicious. I'm a foodie snob, so I'm kind of surprised by some of the less favorable reviews. 

We had an arugula salad with roasted beets and goat cheese, and the pesto pasta with chicken that lured us in. The kitchen split the dishes for us, and even so the portions were plenty (though I'm sure the truffle and biscotti, as well as Piazza's yummy bread helped). We walked away paying about $18 per person with tip, a bargain. Is this the best Italian in the City? No, thus the four stars instead of five. But it's a more casual place for good food at realistic prices. If you want fancy, go to Social or Antica Trattoria.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
This is one of those places where you can taste the quality in the pasta. Sometimes it's easy to get caught up in the sauces, distracted by garnish and flair. But sometimes it's good to get back to the basics. 

Piazza Pellegrini may not be one-hundred percent authentic, but it is one-hundred percent enjoyable. The service is charming, prompt, and very italian.

I ordered the Fettucini with shrimp. The dish avoided all the typical creamy pitfalls surrounding fettucini. The sauce was rich yet smooth and lighter than I had expected. A friend ordered the basil chicken and it was flavorful and aromatic. 

The lobster lasagna was also a treat. 

Overall the experience could best be described as flavorful. The outside sidewalk atmosphere tasteful, yet lively, the service reasonably prompt (for italians), and the food excellent. 

Big thumbs up for this North Beach treasure.
author: Jay C.

description: Very very good meal and competent service.   Great for families.    Rigatoni bolognese is top notch.  Veal parm perfectly prepared.
author: Michael B.

description: Friendly but professional service, nice location and tasty food. We had a great evening.
author: Sinisa N.

description: Fantastic atmosphere, fantastic service and fantastic food. Look forward to my next visit to San Francisco to go back
author: Melissa L.

description: The homemade crab ravioli is to die for! It comes in an aurora sauce which is s creamy tomato sauce. This goes great with a Sauvignon Blanc.
author: Jessica S.

description:
On my very short excursion to San Francisco, I had little in the way of guidance from friends who had been there. As such, my girlfriend and I were mostly on our own to discover what's good and not so good. Fortunately for us, Piazza Pellegrini, found during a random stroll down Columbus, is good. Quite good. 

After being greeted at the door by three very friendly gentlemen with very thick Italian accents, we were promptly seated. I suspect this wouldn't be the case if we weren't looking for dinner at 10pm. 

My significant other ordered the chicken parmesan, a dish she chooses with an almost overwhelming frequency, and I chose the cioppino. Our server brought us some bread with olive oil and balsamic vinegar, which was excellent, to say the least. 

However, the main surprise was dinner itself. The seafood in the cioppino was very fresh and the tomato broth they used was delicious. With that said, I've never had cioppino before, so I have no point of reference. My lady also loved her chicken parm, and as I mentioned above, she's quite the connoisseur. 

As this point, we knew we were already in the hole on the bill, so dessert couldn't possibly do that much more damage. I chose the tiramisu, and she went with the torta caprese. While her dessert followed suit with the rest of dinner, my tiramisu was less than spectacular. The Roxy Deli in NYC and Lost Dog Cafe in Binghamton/Ithaca NY both have me spoiled, I guess. 

Overall, I'm very pleased with the whole experience, and really I'd give the restaurant like 4.8 stars if I could, except then I'd arguably have to round up, and I don't want to give the impression that I thought the place is perfect. Still, amazing experience with friendly wait staff and fantastic food.
author: Matt D.

description: Visited with 3 co-workers on 12/17/12 and had an unfortunate experience.  We were sat near the bar up against the wall.  The basket of bread was delicious and we were enjoying it very much when a ROACH came out from behind the art work on the wall.  We of course screamed and the host came to take care of it with his HAND.  We were re-seated in the middle of the restaurant.  We had already placed our dinner order and didn't know what to do.  It was a first for all of us :-(  Our dinner was served and we could not enjoy it because of what occurred.  We asked for the check and to our dismay the restaurant did not credit us in any way for our poor experience. I could not EVER recommend in good conscience.
author: Cristina I.

description:
Had an early dinner here before seeing Blanket Babylon up  the street. After reading other Yelp reviews I was looking forward to getting the pappardelle with short rib ragu. I started with a ceasar salad which was very mediocre with hardly any flavor - it's bad when you need to use salt on a ceasar salad. The short rib "ragu"? Meh. The ribbon pasta was okay but there was no ragu - just small pieces of overcooked steak sprinkled over the noodles with nothing apporaching a savory gravy. Once again needed salt and pepper.  Other things: bread was decent, but the olive oil/vinegar combo had way too much vinegar and was not good.

Service was adequate and friendly. But you can get better food at Olive garden. Would have been one star but the staff were friendly. A huge disappointment.
author: Rob N.

description:
3.25 stars rounded down to 3 stars.

Cost:
2 dinners, 4 glasses of wine: $79 without tip.

Pros:
* Outdoor seating
* Adequate outdoor heating
* Carbonara was a solid 4 stars
* Gnocchi in gorgonzola cream sauce was a solid 3.5 stars 
* Wine selection is decent

Cons:
* Gnocchi was a bit firm
* Pricey (but the food tends to be a bit high-end)
* The really good wines aren't sold by the glass
* Waiter suggested a wine-by-the-glass because the one we wanted wasn't sold by the glass.  It wasn't a very good substitute.
* Waiter couldn't give me a one word answer as to whether the lasagna was a Bolognese style
* Bus boy freaked out when I asked if we could have oil and vinegar separately instead of pre-combined (for our bread)
author: Jason H.

description:
I live in North beach and typically avoid touristy places, but had a friend in town and she wanted to go here.  The service was ok, but the hostess was doing some work on the table next to us which was unnecessary since it was almost empty.
The bread came and was stale and not very tasty.  It came with oil and balsamic vinegar which was in a small, very small dish.  Oil and  vinegar don't mix so if you put it in a small dish the oil is on top and the vinegar is on the bottom, making it impossible to get both on the bread.  Rookie mistake for an italian restaurant.
I ordered the gnocchi and it was too soft, defeating the purpose of gnocchi for me at least; the texture.  The sauce wasn't anything special either and for 18 dollars it just wasn't worth it.
author: Spencer P.

description:
Things started off promising: friendly waiter, good wine, tasty balsamic with the bread.  Then, I ate some of the real food and was SHOCKED at how awful it was.  My boyfriend and I split some sort of prawn appetizer and the mushroom risotto.  I ate one prawn and didn't go back for more.  I figured, how can they mess up mushroom risotto?  Incredibly salted, underdone, practically inedible.  The only reason why I didn't send it back (which I have never done, by the way) was because we were with a big group for a friend's birthday.  The friends around me were also appalled at the extreme saltiness of their food: the margarita pizza was even saltier than my dish, etc.    

About an hour later, let's just say I was glad we were somewhere with a clean bathroom.  I was in and out of the bathroom for hours!    

I would not recommend this to anyone and I will not be going back.
author: Lauren H.

description:
An extra star for my company at the time.
I thought the servers was rather spotty: some were friendly
while some were "yeah I'll take your guys picture in a minute" only to never return.  It wasn't that busy.

There are ample staff to help you, some just off the boat and warm, others first generation and unable to take your picture.

For a San Francisco restaurant the fact that EVERY dish save one vegetariano had some kind of dead animal in it, was not heartwarming for me.  C'mon every pasta dish? and most of the salads?  Minus a star for that.

The babarra wine was a bit light for my tastes, a later selection poured after we 3 cleared the first bottle, came comped because the waiter who did take our picture wouldn't let us take a picture there without full glasses.  I'd almost give another star for that but come on lessen the meat from the menu, would you?

Lesson, a great place to find shelter from the storm with the best friend,  an endearing new friend, a camera and some wine.
author: Sean S.

description:
We got there around 7:30 on a Saturday night and managed to get a table without a reservation, but just barely! They set a table for four right smack in the middle of the restaurant. The bread basket was filled with yummy soft foccacia carbs and the olive oil/vinegar was divine. I ordered the proscuitto pizza, and it was super salty goodness.

The best part about the restaurant though was the waiter. He was a true Italian. When we ordered, he repeated everything in Italian. Then, when one of us asked to take the food home in a bag, he said "Cosa?" I think because he didn't hear. Then upon returning with the doggie bag, he said, "Ecca la cassa" (Here is the box). Really funny. REALLY ITALIANOOO yeah this place was good. I would go here again. Except still I think the proscuitto pizza is better (if smaller.. perhaps a more reasonable size.. this one had 6 huge slices) at South Beach Cafe, with fresh mozzarella morrissey and basil. Hello!
author: O K.

description:
A friend of mine had parents visiting, and they took out a bunch of us here.  I'm not sure how he found about this place, but I'm glad he did.  It turned out to be a pretty good meal.  

We started with antipasto, then moved onto the fried calamari.  Both were decent.  The calamari could've been a bit more crispy and could've come with more sauce, but overall, it was fine.  Oh, and we had red wine too, but I didn't get a good look at the label, so I couldn't tell you much about it, other than it went perfectly with my choice of entree.  

I got the the osso bucco (lamb shank) as my entree.  There were lots of enticing choices, but I ended up going with something that I usually don't get.  I was glad I did, because it turned out to be pretty darn good.  The meat was juicy and literally fell off the bone.  It came with roasted vegetables, but I was too busy chowing down on the meat to care too much.  

To finish off the meal, I got profiteroles for dessert.  If you've never had this, you're really missing out.  It's pretty much a cream puff with ice cream, instead of regular cream.  Mmm mmm good.  

I don't know how much it came out to, so I can't factor in price as one of the considerations for my rating above.  From what I remember on the menu, the prices seemed pretty reasonable.  I would recommend this place to people looking for a decent Italian place in north beach.
author: Matt P.

description:
This is an ok Italian restaurant in North Beach. We made reservations for a small group and were able to get a table after waiting about 10 minutes after arriving. We had the small seat in the corner by the front window, and it really wasn't big enough for our group. The hostess wasn't very nice, but our service the rest of the time was ok. 

The food wasn't the best Italian I have had. In fact, I wasn't able to finish my dinner as it really wasn't good at all...I actually left hungry and ate bar food later in the evening somewhere else...not exactly the kind of impression you want to have leaving an Italian restaurant. My dinner companions ate most of their food, but still weren't that impressed with their dinners.
author: Cynthia D.

description: As a San Francisco native, I was surprised to find a really tasty italian place to eat with good prices in North Beach. The pastas are good and so are the salads. I have been here with my girlfriend twice and both times we enjoyed our food. i liked my main so much I went home to try to make it myself. A great place for lunch.
author: Max m.

description:
Went here twice -- both times for lunch. 
First time we ordered a pizza (Margharita) and chatted it up with a very friendly and charming waiter as we waited. Pizza was delicious -- it could have been because we were hungover but I don't think so...we devoured it in the car...

Next time we went -- we were seated outside and I ordered a panini (Vegetariano- good) -- and my friend got a pasta dish -- The Cappellini con Pomodorini which was very good, light, and al dente. We again were served by the same charming waiter and if I weren't such a gay, I might have developed a crush.
author: Daniela A.

description:
Simple, yet romantic. They sat us at a corner table overlooking the street. The staff was amazing, the food was delicious, and the waitress suggested a great wine. 

Only complaint was way too much food. I couldn't stop eating so I wound up with a stomach ache from eating too much.
author: T G.

description: Yummy Italian dishes with great service and prices that won't hurt your wallet!
author: Lisa R.

description:
This place is a solid 4 stars. Having tried many Italian restaurants in North Beach and being disappointed, Piazza Pellegrini was a pleasant surprise. Have walked by this place dozens of times not giving it much interest. I am pretty hard to please when it comes to Italian food, mostly because it's really not that hard to make, and shouldn't cost a fortune.

The bread brought out before the meal was quite good. Having foccacia in there was a nice change. The oil and vinegar combo was really tasty for some reason -- they must have used some really good balsamic vinegar. Although it was nice to have some foccacia included in the bread basket, Piazza Pellegrini should think about walking up the block to Liguria to get some REAL focaccia to serve to customers.

Had the gnocchi with sausage, peas, and asparagus, and was very happy overall with the taste and the size of the portion. 

Yes, it is in a strange location. The intersection of Columbus and Filbert is a little funky and doesn't lend itself well to corner restaurants or shops, so you don't get the same sidewalk cafe feel that you would further up the hill on Columbus. All the same, there is still quite a bit of foot traffic.

Once I try all the other Italian restaurants in NB, I'll be back.
author: Brooks S.

description: Dungeness Cioppino was the bomb! Half the pacific ocean was in there. Great location, clean place , excellent wine list. We had reservations for 4 and at last minute added 2 more and they were more than accomodating.
author: Stacey R.

description:
This was my first time (gasp!) in San Francisco, and I needed to eat dinner. A good friend from college lives in the city, so I asked her for advice on where to get some good Italian food. She suggested North Beach and said I could go into any of the restaurants (she promised there'd be tons along Columbus!) and I was guaranteed something to write home about.

So Peter and I ventured from our hotel on Fisherman's Wharf (what a tourist trap!) and drove over to the North Beach area (I would've walked if I had the clothes to withstand the wind -- no one told me SF gets so windy at night!). Piazza Pellegrini was one of the first restaurants we saw, and we couldn't miss it with the twinkle lights on the awning.

We parked right nearby (there was one open parking space right next to the restaurant) and quickly got a table inside.

There were tables right outside, and they had a heat lamp so it was tempting to sit inside -- but like I said, I wasn't dressed for colder weather, so we decided to snag a table indoors. We got a table for two in their crowded dining room (really liked that it was crowded -- kind of gave it a homey atmosphere). It was too brightly lit, which I thought gave the place a sense of intimacy. All the tables had white tablecloths and the place was definitely clean, with a good ambience.

The bread that came out was actually good -- moist and soft. That's always my biggest qualm with bread. I hate the kind that cuts up your mouth when you eat it, so this bread was enjoyable (as was the dipping oil that came with it).

I decided on Cappellini con Pomodorini (angel hair pasta with fresh cherry tomatoes, garlic, olive oil and basil, in a light tomato sauce). Peter got the Fusilli con Pollo (fusilli pasta with fresh chicken breast and basil, in tomato sauce).

We got our dishes pretty quickly, and our waiter was quite amiable. He gave us quick service and wasn't too overbearing nor inattentive. He had a slight accent, which always helps you feel the food is more authentic (hey, not trying to sound ignorant there -- I'd say the same about Chinese restaurants, too).

My Cappellini con Pomodorini was delicious! There's a place back in Houston that makes the same dish, but it has this weird Chinese takeout aftertaste to it. But nooooo... this dish was absolutely fabulous! I could taste the garlic (I love garlic!) subtly, and there wasn't too much olive oil or tomato sauce. I think I liked how light the sauce was, too -- and angel hair pasta is always fun to wind around your fork.

Peter's Fusilli con Pollo wasn't quite up to par, hence my taking a star off. The chicken was a bit dry, I'd say, and I didn't like the taste of his tomato sauce as much as my own. (Pete definitely took forkfuls of my pasta off my plate, which is how I also knew his wasn't quite up to par...)

All in all, the visit was a success -- we were famished and I got my fill of yummy Italian food (although Pete's dish was lacking...) and a pleasant atmosphere (with easy parking!).
author: Helen C.

description:
I wanted Italian Food and that's exactly what I got for dinner.  Luis and I decided to head out to Piazza Pellegrini after drinking at Lou's at the Square.    We arrived at the restaurant before the crowd so we got a nice table for two by the window.  

We ordered no drinks, just iced water.  For starters with the bread, we had the Fritto Misto di Pesce  (fried fresh calamari and shrimp) -- lightly battered and not oily.  Both ordered a bowl of Minestrone soup with our meal -- served in big bowl, lots of veggies...tasty!  For my main entree, I had the Cappellini con Pomodorini (angel hair pasta with garden cherry tomatoes, garlic, olive oil and basil, in light tomato sauce) -- delicious, just what I wanted.  Luis had the Veal Parmigiana (breaded slice of veal 
 with tomato and parmigiana,  served with potatoes and vegetable) -- he seemed to have liked it a lot.  

Such big portions that we didn't have room for dessert, but there's always next time.
author: Celeste M.

description: This place is awesome. People are wonderful! We had the gnocchi, it was delicious. They even made mine extra spicy. Made us feel very welcome and comfortable. Would recommend to anyone interested in trying authentic Italian in a relaxed cool atmosphere.
author: Allison M.

description:
I should have been prepared to eat on Italy time. I don't want to base my review entirely on the slow service, but on a hot day in a hot restaurant (no AC or strong fans) I want to eat fairly fast. That's not to say eat "in a rush" but if puddles start forming at my feet it's a bad sign. Yeah, well, we couldn't wait to leave we were so uncomfortable. Maybe I just went on a bad day...

The veggie pizza is thin crust and just lightly layered with some broccoli, cauliflower and not much else. The rest of the menu looked good and the gelato was calling to me... Maybe if I'd ordered some I would have been able to stand the heat.
author: Robyn L.

description:
Awesome.
Awesome, Awesome, Awesome.

My boyfriend and I happened here on accident, and decided to try it.  I'm very glad we did!

The table bread was delicious, and served with a side of olive oil mixed with balsamic.  YUM.  The busser was very attentive, and stopped by the table many times throughout the evening to refill the oil and bv dip.

My boyfriend and I shared a caprese salad to start, and it was large and in charge!  The mozzerella was thick and very fresh.  The tomatoes were half red, half yellow.  It was very, very good, and everything tasted very, very fresh.

For entrees, I had a special of the night, crab ravioli.
My boyfriend ordered of the normal menu and had the rabbit.

Both were amazing!  The ravioli was clearly handmade, and cooked to a perfect al dente.  They were stuffed with real crab meat, and topped off with a tomato cream sauce and more chunks of crab meat.

The rabbit was bunnylicious!  It was half a rabbit, in a reduction sauce, over vegetables and polenta.  My boyfriend isn't normally too psyched about polenta, but this polenta was creamy and almost the texture of mashed potatoes and he loved it!!

We were so stuffed, we passed on dessert.

We ate our entire meal sitting outside on the street.  It really was a perfect experience.

The price was right, for everything to eat and a few drinks the bill came out to a whopping 49$
Not too shabby.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Every time I come to San Francisco I have to get my dose of Italian in North Beach.  Last night my cousin took me to Piazza Pelligrini, and it satisfied my craving for yummy Italian food.  

North Beach on a Saturday night is crazy - no parking, long waits... we had to wait about a half an hour for a table for four, but we were able to wait at the bar (thank goodness because it was FREEZING outside - this So. Cal girl can't handle the SF weather!)  

Once we were seated we were able to order promptly and the food arrived fairly quickly.  The Calamari starter was standard - good.  We all ordered pasta, and we were all happy with our selections.  I ordered the Cappelini Pomodoro (pretty boring, I know) but it was WONDERFUL!  My cousin ordered the bologenese and it was super tasty as well (kind of wishing I would have had that) - the noodles were home made and perfectly cooked.  My Fiance had the frute de mere pasta and loved it!  We were so full after the pasta that we stopped there, but the tiramisu looked wonderful... maybe next tie we'll save room for dessert.
author: Mariah C.

description: Excellent food but the service was what made my evening here. Friendly, welcoming and attentive.... genuine old fashioned hospitality that is lacking at so many other places.  Outside tables are great for people watching, too.
author: Laney J.

description:
I've walked by this place twice and decided to give it a try. There is outdoor seating which is nice for those warm evenings. We sat at a table inside. I was feeling adventurous this evening so I tried the rabbit. I've never had rabbit before but I am always willing to try new things. It was kind of dry, had a funny taste, and wayyyy too many bones for me. 

My friend had the gnocchi and that was pretty good. 

What was really good was the bread with the dipping oil. 

We were so stuffed! The dessert menu looked delish and I will have to come back to try them one of these days.

The service was a bit.....lacking. You really have to flag someone down if you need something.

I have been living in SF for five months.  A friend came to visit for the weekend, so we were tourists for a few days.  I took her to beautiful North Beach hoping to stumble across some great Italian food.  I know so many places in the neighborhood are big tourist traps and I don't know how to pick out a good place.

But I was very happy with my choice to stop by Piazza Pellegrini.  At times I felt like I was in Italy.  The service was wonderful and so many delicious dishes to choose from.  We split a salad, but wanted to try them all.  The gorgonzola with pear was delightful, except for the weedy pieces of greens.  Pizza with the thin ham was not too flavorful and my guest said she likes her thin pizzas a little thinner and "floppier."

It was nice to find a real authentic place, but it was not the best.  But we enjoyed what we were served and enjoyed our time.  Despite the harsh rating from our trip, I would recommend it.
author: Julie R.

description:
Went here while vacationing in San Fran.  I wish I had a yelp guide for top restaurants every single time I'm out, I feel so lost when we try to go eat somewhere and we are computer-less.  Anyways, on a whim, we decided to eat here.  It was a week day and pretty packed, so we figured it couldn't be that bad.

App - Shared a salad, nothing special, but yummy nonetheless.  Then we waited.. and continued to wait for our entrees for about 30 min.
Entrees - When they finally did come out, I got the lamb chops.  OK, nothing great or fantastic.  My bf got ravioli, still good, but it came with an alfredo sauce that wasn't expected.  

No dessert for the evening and bill for two people with 2 glasses of house red was $88.  Def. not a show stopper.
author: Cindy H.

description:
I don't know how many times we've walked by this place and said we'll need to try it one of these days.  Each time we pass by, we see plates of delicious pasta and the outdoor seating is always full...so why wait?  Not sure BUT we finally had a taste of this place at the Boss of Sauce event a few weeks ago and their sauce was one of our favorites.  

We had been debating for weeks where to dine for our anniversary but we couldn't decide and never made reservation anywhere although we were always thinking French.  Even up to the day of, we were still debating on La Folie and up to hours before thinking about Rue Lepic or Jeanne D'arc.  As a result of a late and filling lunch at another french restaurant, we were just sitting idled until late.  By the time we were ready for dinner, we decided to just walk down the street and see where it may lead us.  By now, I didn't care for anything fancy but just a cozy place with good food.  

After passing by a couple places we would consider but seeing how busy and noisy they were, we continued on and came upon Piazza Pellegrini.  It was busy but somehow it felt right.  We waited about 5 minutes before we were led to a table inside. 

Service was fantastic.  We were given water as soon as we sat down.  The basket of bread came shortly after - a basket of bread and cubes of foccacia with a small plate of dipping olive oil with balsamic vinegar (the vinegar was so tasty).  The waiter was very friendly and helpful.  We were debating on a few things and he helped us decide easily.  

Special appetizer - $11.95 - warm white asparagus spears over a bed of greens with mozarella and prosciutto bits drizzled with olive oil.  Tasty but somehow I wish cool or cold and not warm.  

Fettucini special - $19.95 - homemade fettucini with prawns with arugula in a tomato sauce.  The fettucini was very tasty and chewy and the arugula adds a nice nutty flavor.  

Home Made Pappardelle Pellegrini - $16.95 - ribbon pasta with short rib ragû.  The pappardelle was al dente and it was wide and long.  Hubby really enjoyed the short rib ragu, especially the tasty bits of short ribs.  

A half bottle of classico reserve chianti - $25 - it was very good, smooth and a little sweet.  

For dessert - Canolo Siciliano - $7 - chocolate crusted canolo filled with ricotta cheese and candied fruits.  This was probably the most disappointing dish of the evening.  It was very dense and the shell was not crispy, almost stale.  However, the flavor was enhanced with the chocolate and raspberry sauce that was drizzled on top and around.  

We will definitely come back for their pasta - I have my eye on the Spaghetti ai Frutti di Mare.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I run past this place all the time, and there is always a waiter dressed in white who tempts my smelly, sweaty self into the restaurant.  He darn near gets me everytime.

Not only is the Papardelle Pellegrini is not only fun to say, but it's also pretty darn amazing as well.  This place is great - good service, friendly (and fun) waiters, and mouth-watering food.  Buon appetito!
author: Athena ..

description: What a sweet little restaurant with outdoor seating. Had a Margherita pizza and glass of wine out on the sidewalk. Pizza was wonderful, service was fantastic and the people watching was fabulous!  Will definitely return to try some pasta.
author: Lisa D.

description: Friday night service eas spotty, but the food was spectacularly dull. The homemade meat ravioli truly disappointed.
author: Jason V.

description: I just moved to the Bay area and after many visits to this restaurant before I will ALWAYS continue going. EXCELLENT food. Very authentic if you like Italian. Every dish I have ordered has always been cooked to perfection! Do not have one complaint to make. The service is wonderful. You feel as if they genuinely are happy to have you as a customer. My favorite restaurant in all the bay area!!
author: Laura M.

description: Pizza at cafe cable car was "ok" but the service was bad.  I asked for water 3 times and finally just got up to get it myself. $7.95 for a slice of pizza -- tourist trap for sure!
author: Rayna A.

description:
I liked this place. My dad, his new girlfriend, two of my sisters, and my brother flew up from Palm Spring the other weekend and we ate here on one of the nights they were in town.

I ordered the capellini pomodoro (I think...it was angel hair with a light tomato sauce.)

The pasta was really good as was the tiramisu (sorry for all the spelling mistakes...see what finals do to me?) for desert! And the service wasn't bad either. I'm glad I ate here as my first experience in North Beach. I'm going to take my boyfriend there one of these nights and see what he thinks.

If anyone has a suggestion as to where I should try that might be better, let me know! I wanna go there!
author: Britany L.

description:
We were headed back to the city from wine tasting in the Santa Cruz mountains, and one of us was craving Italian.  I looked up opentable.com's website on my phone and found they Piazza Pellegrini had an open table at an appropriate time.  We booked it.

The server was so happy!  Honestly, the happiest, jolliest guy I've ever seen.  He recommended a tasty, well-priced Italian wine.   And we all started with cesare salads (very anchovy-tasting, but I like anchovies, so I liked the salad).

It went slightly down hill from there.

Basically, everyone liked their food but me.  I asked for their crab ravioli special.  It was pretty bland.  My fiancee had their rigatoni bolognese, which was tasty.  His sister had a margherita pizza, which was yummy.  Her husband had their pork chop with gorgonzola cream sauce, which they all raved about (I don't like gorgonzola, so I didn't try it).

For dessert, we ordered their hazelnut gelato in pastry puffs, their flourless chocolate cake, and something else I can't remember.  The pastry puffs were too thick, but the gelato was great, as was the chocolate cake.

Three of us also ordered cappucino's with dessert, which were solid.  The fourth ordered port, which he commented was delish (maybe not his exact word).

Anyway, it was good food.  Just don't get the crab ravioli.
author: S J.

description:
New Year's Eve Day wandering SF looking for a new Italian place we happened on Piazza Pelligrini, right off Washington Square. Ok, so not happened, I did Yelp Italian in the area. A bit of cruising for a spot and we trundled in. Just a few tables, they wanted us to share, but we opted to wait for our own.
Anticipation! Ah the smell... yum!
They start you off with bread and basilic. The bread was incredible... I probably ate too much, but oh well. Then on to the main course. Ok so it was sorta late lunch so we rolled with a couple of calzone... one meat and one veggie and one panini. The calzone were excellent (ok overused adjective), incredible crust and my meat one included roasted red peppers and caramelized onions. My wife got the panini and was completely overwhelmed, way too much chicken! But loved it.
We were sooooo stuff, we had to skip dessert, but next time we definitely will save room.
Service: totally attentive. Our waiter (owner?) even suggested the spiced oil for the calzone... great choice if you like hot. And when we left he even escorted us out the door to say goodbye.
This is one of our new favorites. We'll be back!
author: Curt A.

description: Thanks to Yelp and OpenTable, my wife and family chose this restaurant based on the proximity to Cobb's Comedy Club, as we wanted to dine within a short walking distance from the club. We walked in and found a very warm and inviting environment, a small and cozy restaurant with a very accommodating staff. So accommodating, in fact, that they presented us with a delicious plate of free appetizers due to the fact that we couldn't be seated for our 8:30 reservation on time because of a table of lingering diners. The food was delicious, rich and plentiful. If you enjoy robust and authentic Italian cuisine, this is the place for you!
author: K. V.

description: It's Friday night, I wanted a simple Italian meal before the Escape From Alcatraz race the next day . . .this place was right up the street from my hotel and had an open table.  Definitely a place targeting tourists, a great location with sidewalk tables and pretty good service.  Not sure if the accents a real, but they add a nice touch.  I was really disappointed in the spinach salad, the dressing was not a good match for the salad.  The dungeness crab ravioli was very tasty and recommend.  I thought the prices were reasonable.
author: Whitney P.

description:
Really should be a 3.5 rating.......

I had a fettucine dish that had won some award for them and it was fantastic.  Had onions, tomatoes, and pancetta in it along with two big meatballs.   It was delicious homemade pasta.  I really enjoyed this dish. 

The wife had a salad that was really small and very generic ($9).  Could have poured it right out of a bag.  Also thought the bread was low quality.  

Loved their split bottle wine selection.  

Service was ok.  They were slammed and I understand that.  It is a pretty small place inside and tables are tight.  There are tables outside as well.
author: Jason M.

description:
This HORRIBLE restaurant deserves 0 stars or even a negative if it were possible. The wait staff was rude: he never actually made eye contact with anyone at our group's table and after taking our order NEVER CAME BACK. We had t ask three seperate people for the check because our waiter was too busy texting and talking on the phone outside. 
THE FOOD... was the worst! The pizza was burnt, the fettucini had NO FLAVOR (I have made better with the canned alfredo sauce); salt was added to give the food some sort of taste and the chicken was rubbery. 

ALL IN ALL, the worst "italian" (if you can even call it that) restaurant in North Beach... maybe even the worst eatery in San Fran.

Do yourself a favor and when you see this seemingly cute whole in the wall... KEEP WALKING!!!
author: ashley n.

description:
Looking of neighborhood Italian?

This fits the bill....  I ran away from this place once because the dude out front starts to sing at you when you walk by... I hate that @$it, but I went back because I had a good feeling about.... 

Sure enough..  Good, well prepared Italian...  Minus= the smallest plate of carbonara I ever saw...  I grew up with Italians...  they would break your fingers for offering such small portions...  It's not the way we do things back home...  back home being: good home cooking... Italian or Chinese...  (same thing, dark hair, dark eyes, and guilt)
author: Alex K.

description:
I am a Yelp addict, but felt the need to finally create an account after today's fairly pitiful experience at Piazza Pellegrini.

My fiance and I headed over to North Beach today to itch a craving for Italian that we've had.  By the time we reached Powell and Columbus we were so famished that we jumped into the first place we saw, which happened to be PP.

From the time we got there I was not impressed.  To sum it up, the servers barely acknowledged the outside crowd (The guys next to us sat there for almost 15 minutes before someone actually came to take their order and bring them water).  We had to ask three different people to bring us our check, I actually had to get up to go inside and ask for our check. NO ONE checked on us at all throughout the course of our meal, we had to flag down a busboy to refill our empty water glasses, and the food was, as my other-half put it "entry-level" for Italian at best.  I was seriously ticked off by the time we left.  Our salad came out missing an ingredient, my dish was bland, his had a funny after-taste, all-in-all, we'll be avoiding this place from this point forward.  There is MUCH better food and service to be had in North Beach and the city as a whole.
author: Chrys W.

description: We stopped in for coffee and dessert.  The waiter walked away from us shaking his head when we told him this - it was a Tuesday night - not crowded.  He was clearly angry that it would not be a big bill with a big tip - the service was non existent - horrible - and the dessert was stale.  I would never go back.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Great Italian restaurant.  Best for slow, relaxed, and enjoyable dining.  Piazza Pellegrini has a great selection of wines, great service, delightful ambiance, and a tasty assortment of traditional Italian food with some nice unique choices and specials.  Of note, the menu was not very vegetarian friendly, but there were certainly a few choices.

We drank a Pinot Noir, and while it was lighter than expected, it was tasty and went well with the meal.  I tried the special squash ravioli and the menu pesto ravioli.  Both were good vegetarian choices, and rich with flavor.  Dessert was a fruit tart, which was too tart for me.

Service was impeccable and the folks working there really made the meal.  They never rushed us, but were always available.

Slightly expensive (almost $20 for pasta), but worth it for the experience.  Go for a wonderful time, not for a quick meal.

Food gets 3 stars, but overall definitely a four star dinner.
author: Aaron R.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for the weekend, we stopped at Piazza Pellegrini for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. The restaurant had some customers when we arrived, but was very full by the time we left. It was surprising how many people it could actually seat. 

The food was very good, but not excellent. I ordered lasagna which is an Italian staple that most restaurants tend to serve very dry and bland. However, this was the best lasagna I have had at a restaurant. The desert wasn't so good which is why I gave three instead of four stars.

The atmosphere has a sense of formality, but the customers were a mix of fine dining and tourist who happened to be in the area. We spent just over $100 on lunch for two, dessert and graduity so I would consider it pricey. The staff do their jobs, but I wouldn't call them friendly by any means (the second reason for 3 out of 4 stars).
author: A. R.

description:
Great food, but there is room for improvement. The wife and I went there for the first time the other day and overall it is a four star place, based on the strength of the main events: the appetizers, salads and the main courses.

They started off with a mixed bag: bad bread (tasteless) with excellent olive oil/balsamic vinegar dip. The wife loved the balsamic vinegar so much we bought a bottle. Speaking of bottles, we brought our own bottle of wine, which the waiter gladly opened and poured (we had him bring an extra glass so that he could have a taste too).

We started with the Timballo di Verdura appetizer, which consists of layers of grilled vegetables, tomatoes and mozzarella. It was great - we could have had two or three of these. She had the Insalta Mista while I had the spinach salad. She loved hers and I liked mine (I've had better, but this was good). For the main course she had the Farfallette al Salmone Affumicato (bowtie pasta with smoked salmon, peas, dill and vodka, in light cream tomato sauce) while I had the crab ravioli with pesto sauce. Both of these were perfectly done and tasted excellent. My raviolis were stuffed with great tasting crab, and the blend of ingredients in her dinner worked perfectly.

So after starting off on a sour note with the bad bread (but excellent dip) and then having an excellent meal we finished with the desserts. Neither one (my Torta Caprese - light flourless chocolate cake served with raspberry sauce - and her Crostata di Mele - crisp short pastry crust topped with apples and apricot glaze served with vanilla gelato) matched the excellence of the meal.

One minor quibble on service is that our waiter never offered fresh ground pepper or fresh ground parmesan cheese (both of which we saw used at other tables after our need for them was gone).

The biggest negative point for me was the music. Whatever it was, it was unrecognizable and unpleasant. This is an Italian bistro. Play some nice Italian music or opera or something. Or some really nice dinner jazz. Something that is pleasant to eat a wonderful meal with. This is a bit of a deal-breaker with me, so hopefully they read this and modify their sound mix before my next visit!

So like I said up front: great food, with room for improvement.
author: Jerry P.

description:
One thing that impresses me about San Francisco is the genuine quality of the food.  I visited the city by the bay for business this winter and dined at Piazza Pellegrini for lunch.  Off the bat I was captivated by the friendliness of the waiter greeting everyone and trying to get people into the restaurant.  Thankfully my business group chose this place.
In keeping with the genuine aspect of the restaurant, of course, our waiter and all the staff was of obvious italian decent.  Our waiter in particular resembled a short, italian version of Robert Downey Jr with the voice of Mario from the classic nintendo games.  They were quick to get our drink orders and put out some bread and oil and vinegar.  I never thought I would ever say this - but that was the best vinegar I have ever had.  It had a sweet taste to it that kept my tastebuds wanting more.  And more.
Now for the entrees - I ordered the salmon pizza.  I wish it hadnt looked so delicious so I  could have taken a picture.  It was incredible.  The dough had been baked crispy on the outside and soft on the inside - they somehow didnt over bake the salmon either.  It was of perfect consistency.  The taste was something I had never experienced.  This was my first fish pizza - amazing.  If you like salmon I totally recommend this dish.
The restaurant had a food delivery while we waited for our check.  It came to us late because our server decided to banter with the italian delivery guy who towered at easily 6'5".  It was very entertaining to hear them talk.
All in all - a classic experience.  I highly recommend this place.  Dont be a chump - visit Piazza Pellegrini and order the salmon pizza.
author: Joe E.

description:
the restaurants in north beach just try to pack in as many tiny tables and chairs in their dining room as physically possible...
it does create a cozy feel to it, but i tend to feel quite claustrophobic at these places...
then they put the overflow of tables and chairs outside stretching as much of the sidewalk they can... this place even has a couple tables right by the parking lot next to the building... and that's where we sat...
the food was decent
the waitstaff personalities are a bit over the top when clearly they're quite indifferent about you...
author: charlotte s.

description:
Living near North Beach, one of the must do's is to go exploring during dinner time.  We walked into this restaurant because we parked near it, and that's the truth.  

I'm glad we picked this place because I was strangely craving for risotto, and they had it as one of their specials that night!  We ordered the shrimp risotto *delicious* as our entree along with a green salad *yum* and a clam & mussels combo in white wine sauce as a starter *delicious&yum*.  Since we were so stuffed but couldn't resist skipping dessert, we ordered tiramisu to go.  I've never had tiramisu with tiny chocolate chips all over.  It was good, until the chocolate chips got too overpowering.  If you have a super sweet tooth, it's your dessert.

The place is good, give it a try!
author: Ibbs K.

description: Highly recommended!! Had the gnocchi with sausage, asparagus, and gorgonzola cream sauce, and Giant seared scallops with rissoto. Both were amazing! Great atmosphere, great service. Tom was our server, he was outstanding. Very helpful, and knowledgable of their menu.
author: Todd C.

description:
Disappointingly, the lobster ravioli was served al dente - and the lobster just didn't taste fresh or flavorful. The appetizer was better (caprese) but nothing to write home about. Overall just sort of blah. 

I was more disappointed in the food because I've been to this restaurant many years ago (4 years ago) and the food was so much better. Not sure what has happened but it really disappointed me this time.
author: Latte Queen W.

description: We dined here with some family members at their recommendation and I can see why they suggested it.  Seating was quick and efficient and their menu contained something Italian for every palette.  Service was friendly - even entertaining at times and great overall.  The food was stellar.  I had the Prosciutto and Melon special on the appetizer menu and Gnocchi on the regular menu.  The prosciutto was melt in your mouth tender and the melon fresh and very sweet.  The gnocchi was tossed in a Gorgonzola sauce with some asparagus and sausage.  It was all fantastic - and I topped it off with some wonderful Profiterole (pastry puffs with hazelnut ice cream - does it get any better?).   I'll be back here for sure on our next San Fran trip.
author: Jeaux B.

description:
Fun outdoor seating with good people watching.  Service was friendly and attentive.  
Bread- pretty generic and a bit stale.  
We had a Caprese salad with the freshest mozarella- that was the best dish. 
 The rest of the food (Insalata Mista, Prosciutto pizza and squash ravioli)   was pretty good, but I am not giving it more than 3 stars because all the dishes were saturated in olive oil!   All of the food tasted  so overwhelmingly of olive oil, it was hard to discern any other flavors!
author: irene c.

description:
From the outside, the place looks great!

However, the service was slow and lacking.  The waiter was whining, complaining, and making excuses why he couldn't help us.  No tip for you buddy.

The food was forgettable, overpriced, and Domino's makes a better pizza.

Unpleasant from beginning to end.
author: Noah B.

description: YAY!!! I really love to stop by here when in San Fran. It's a great cafe` with outdoor seating for us city folk who like to people watch and don't mind traffic buzzing by as we eat. The owner his from Italy and will tell you a story or two if he has time. They have excellent food and a nice wine list. The service is excellent and very friendly. We recommend you make reservations on the weekends or you'll wait till you decide to leave..lol - we locked our keys in the car one night and the waiter was so awesome, He gave us a coat hanger and checked on us often to make sure we were ok. It was embarassing, but we felt the kindness. It's become one of our GO TO stops in San Fran for excellent, authentic italian food.
author: Debra A.

description:
I went with some family that was in town and everything was pretty much spot on.  The prices were right, the service was excellent, and very Italian, and the food was delicious.  I had the fettucini alfredo with prawns and peas.  They really do an Italian/Continental-style meal in that "Primi" dishes are in fact smaller portions than "Secondi."  My mom had the lamb shanks and she said they were literally falling off the bone--super tender.  She asked our server about them and he said they'd been cooked for six hours.  The salads are great.  The desserts are great.  And their house balsamic vinegar is probably the best I've tasted in my limited opinion.

Edit: Went back once or twice since then and the service wasn't nearly as good and the lamb tasted kinda weird.  So, hit and miss I guess.
author: Colin W.

description:
In your face service---wait, service isn't the right word; try harassment---that was degrading to the women in our party.  Cultural differences be damned: these guys were tacky and tasteless.  And when the men are paying the bill, the least you can do if fill up their glasses once in a while.

Oh, and the food sucked too.  The seafood pasta featured slim pickings.  My crab ravioli tasted remarkably dull---way to kill dungeness crab, guys.

How's about less time hitting on women and more time working on the recipes!
author: Christian W.

description:
Interesting... a lot of good and some not-so good. The service was excellent. I liked the decor and very welcoming feel of the restaurant; I liked the open kitchen, i.e., being able to make eye contact with the chefs, and watch them in action. The music was great but a little too loud; I had to shout in order for my not-deaf boyfriend to hear me. Now about the food...

What's interesting is that some of the food was excellent, and some was pretty bad. For example, the bread was stale, or it seemed that it had been sliced early in the day and left to sit until the evening--but, the balsamic vinegar was really good! I mean, the best balsamic vinegar ever! So I kept eating the bread anyway, just because I liked the vinegar so much.

My dinner--I had the rabbit. The sauce was good, though a bit too salty. The meat seemed too dry, even though I believe rabbit tends to already BE a dry meat--but, I felt like I had to struggle with the meat to get it off the bone. However, the polenta that accompanied the rabbit dish was the best I've ever had--incredibly buttery and rich in flavor. The vegetables on the side were also perfectly crisp and fresh. 

I'd say I MIGHT go back and give it another try... Was it good? Was it not good? Hmm...
author: J K.

description: Nice setting and location but overpriced and disappointing. My wife couldn't finish her soggy sandwich. My gnocchi was a little better. Service was only fair.
author: M G.

description: I ordered the Chicken Parmigiana and it was alright but I would say a small portion considering it cost $19.00!  The most hilarious part was after we had finished eating the hostess took the flowers off our table at the end of the meal and placed them on another table for another set of guests!
author: Ryan T.

description: Again, I should have checked what my fellow yelp users had to say about this place before going, but I was curios after a couple mentioned it to the chef at our bed and breakfast. Therefore for dinner we headed to this place. When we arrived we opted to go and dine at the bar, which almost ment "will get ignored", if it was't for another couple that required we move over a stool, at which point my husband asked the host for a server to tae care of us, we would still be waiting. My husband and I decided to share a black spaghetti with salmon because I was not that hungry. The bread they gave us tasted stale and was really nothing special. The pasta had great taste, but it was $24, an outrageous price compared to a similar better dish in Soho NYC. Furthermore I was also annoyed that this place did not make fresh sangria. To top it all off, we asked for our check and we were pleasantly surprised by a $4 sprite plus tax...not!!! Overpriced 100%
author: B D.

description:
grabbed a sandwich for lunch here on friday after my last day at fundraising school @ the marriott @ fisherman's wharf. 

came with a friend and my bf and was so excited for a panini. it wasn't a typical panini, but more like a sandwich, a dry one. 

i ordered the chicken panini, which came with chicken, pesto, and a huge roll of bread.. too much bread, not enough juices and it was terribly dry. 

saving grace is that 1 dish was ok, 1 was bad, 1 was good. i may give them another chance, but definitely not the same sandwich. 

they did have tasty bread and olive oil/balsamic to start and it was a beautiful sunny day in the city :)
author: Art A.

description: Uninspired. Mediocre. Enough said.  I suspect the 3 and 4 star reviews are mostly from tourists.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Came here on a beautiful afternoon for lunch.  Enjoyed the experience for everything but the food.  I had a tasteless ceasar salad.  The bread was okay, but they were very stingy on the olive oil dipping sauce.  I might give it another try, but probably not.  Too many other places to eat.
author: Kevin M.

description: Excellent homemade pastas! Sit street side and people watch.
author: Matthew B.

description: I don't understand the negative reviews on this place. My server was more than attentive, and the food was delicious. I'd recommend ordering one of their specials. They make their pasta from scratch, and they utilize fresh fish in their seafood dishes. Some of the staff speaks Italian (not just "buona sera" and "prego"), which to me is a potential indicator that it's an authentic Italian restaurant. They're even open on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day! The only negative comment I have is that the dessert I ordered was covered in chocolate syrup, which made it too rich (and not authentically Italian).
author: Jason M.

description: Ehhhhh.... I really want to like this place, but it's just buried in mediocrity. The location is prime which gives it points for convenience, but the food is just ok. I ordered the roasted chicken which was tough and flavorless. It came with veggies which were dripping in oil. Good thing I filled up on bread, cause the service was nothing special and I was starving by the time my food came. There's just too many amazing places in North Beach to waste your time on anything less than spectacular.
author: Kelly N.

description: I found this place very quaint.  The food was good and the service was very responsive.  We had a 5:00 reservation and got there a bit before 4:30 and they seated us early.
